What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of practical skills for biochemistry lab and how to write a lab report

Experiments: PCR, Restriction Digestion and Ligation of PCR Products and Phage Vector, Transformation of Competent E. coli, Enzyme Activity Assay, Isolation of Single-Stranded DNA, DNA Sequencing and Sequence Analysis, Structural Analysis of Protein Folding, Protein Purification, SDS-PAGE Analysis of Protein Purification, Enzyme Kinetics

Discussion of major developments and methods in biochemistry. Assistance with authoring a final lab report.
I learned many basic molecular biology techniques including cloning, transformation, PCR, protein purification, enzyme kinetics, as well as how to use PyMOL and write a proper scientific article.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths were the organization, dedication of the professor and TA, and collaborative work with other students. No weaknesses.

There were a lot of strengths to this course. The virtual lectures were productive and very engaging. Throughout the semester there was a good mix of quizzes, virtual labs, and in-class assignments, and the teaching staff was always available to assist with assignments. The in-person labs were genuinely interesting and fun. We received a lot of help and feedback with the final lab report. Because the course was half-term, it was a lot of concentrated work and occasionally felt a bit rushed. However, the teaching staff did their best to fill in any gaps in understanding and the schedule. I would have liked the opportunity to spend more time in the lab in-person, but the time we did get was productive and considering COVID restrictions it was nice to get any in-person instruction at all.

The TA and the professor were both very kind, open, and accommodating. They definitely did their best to put a lab (!) online and although classes were often very long, it was a lot of time spent on Zoom for both students and professors so I appreciate all the effort they put in. 
The weakness was that as I write this evaluation, a week after the class has ended, I am only just now receiving grades for quizzes which were taken over a month ago. It's difficult to get an idea of how you are doing in a class/if you need to improve some aspect if you don't receive the vast majority of your grades until the very end of the course, or even after it is over.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked the experience online, as the professor did everything in her power to give us an engaging learning experience.

I think the lectures were well adapted to the virtual setting. I think the least successful virtual component was the Labster online labs, which I felt weren't particularly helpful to complete and ended up just being busywork. Because of the hybrid format we had a lot less time actually in the lab, and some experiments felt a bit rushed, but the time we spent in lab was helpful, useful, and fun.

I honestly liked the Labster virtual labs; they were sort of silly but I definitely got a good sense of the technique. Sometimes lectures got behind and went over time; also, in the beginning of the course we watched a lot of documentaries on Zoom, and while they were interesting, I don't feel like they were related enough to the course for me to want to spend an extra hour on Zoom. Because of the duration of this class, the Zoom fatigue definitely got pretty severe, although I really appreciate the yoga and meditation breaks which were built in.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I think it was a great way to learn practical lab skills as well as meet an amazing MB&B professor!

Yes, I would recommend this course to students taking biochemistry lecture, as well as students who don't have a ton of research experience and want to learn some very useful laboratory techniques. I personally enjoyed the boot-camp mentality of the half-term course, and I learned so much in such a short amount of time. Also, the teaching staff genuinely cares about helping you learn the content, develop your laboratory skills, and become a better scientist.

Overall, this is a great survey of some foundation molecular biology techniques. If you work in a lab, you have probably used them before, and may want to use the waiver to get out of this course. However, I still enjoyed it and felt like I got a lot out of some of the psets and final paper, so it was definitely not a waste of time. Also, the teaching staff are great to get to know, and I imagine if it was in person it would be a fun class to be in.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This was a hybrid lab with live virtual lectures and in-person lab sessions.
Virtual lab with virtual lectures, optional in-person component (did not take).
